facts.text: Appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1963 by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated September 5, 1962 in Criminal Appeal No. 295 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 5, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 295 of 1960. K. Chakravarty, for the appellant. Sarjoo Prasad, E. Udayarathnam and R. C. Prasad, for res- pondent No. 2.

facts.text: Appellant Rajeswar Prosad Misra convicted under s. 408 IPC on three counts and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year and fine of Rs. 2000, in default 6 months further RI.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Rajeswar Prosad Misra, who has been companyvicted under s. 408 of the Indian Penal Code on three companynts and sentenced in the aggregate to suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000  in default 6 months further rigorous imprisonment , was a traveling salesman of Messrs. Dabur  Dr. S. K. Burman  Private Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant was traveling salesman of Messrs. Dabur Dr. S. K. Burman Private Ltd operating in Suburbs of Calcutta and Mill Area.

anchor.surface_text: The area of his operation was the Suburbs of Calcutta and the Mill Area. His duty was to secure orders from Agents and to effect delivery of goods to them in the Companys vans. He was required to receive payments from the agents and to deposit the money with the cashier of the Company.

facts.text: On 10th February 1958, appellant received Rs. 300 on behalf of company from Isaq and Son.

anchor.surface_text: The three charges on which he was tried and companyvicted were on 10th and 19th February, 1958 die received, on behalf of the Company, sums of Rs. 300 and Rs. 240 respectively, from a firm Isaq and Son.,, and on 3rd May, 1958 a sum of Rs. 1502 from Bombay Fancy Stores, but failed to deposit these sums with the cashier.

facts.text: On 19th February 1958, appellant received Rs. 240 on behalf of company from Isaq and Son.

anchor.surface_text: The three charges on which he was tried and companyvicted were on 10th and 19th February, 1958 die received, on behalf of the Company, sums of Rs. 300 and Rs. 240 respectively, from a firm Isaq and Son.,, and on 3rd May, 1958 a sum of Rs. 1502 from Bombay Fancy Stores, but failed to deposit these sums with the cashier.

facts.text: On 3rd May 1958, appellant received Rs. 1502 on behalf of company from Bombay Fancy Stores.

anchor.surface_text: The three charges on which he was tried and companyvicted were on 10th and 19th February, 1958 die received, on behalf of the Company, sums of Rs. 300 and Rs. 240 respectively, from a firm Isaq and Son.,, and on 3rd May, 1958 a sum of Rs. 1502 from Bombay Fancy Stores, but failed to deposit these sums with the cashier.

facts.text: Appellant failed to deposit the sums of Rs.300, Rs.240 and Rs.1502 with the company cashier.

anchor.surface_text: but failed to deposit these sums with the cashier. A companyplaint was accordingly filed against him in the Court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on August 29, 1958.

facts.text: Complaint filed against appellant in Court of Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on August 29, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint was accordingly filed against him in the Court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on August 29, 1958. The charges were framed against him under s. 408 I.P.C. on July 16, 1959.

facts.text: Charges framed against appellant under s.408 IPC on July 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The charges were framed against him under s. 408 I.P.C. on July 16, 1959. The prosecution proved the receipt of the money by him and his failure to deposit it with the cashier.

facts.text: Appellant's defence was that he had deposited the amounts and case was counter-blast to dispute with V.D. Srivastava.

anchor.surface_text: His defence was that he had deposited the amount and that the case was started against him as a companynter-blast to a dispute between him and V. D. Srivastava, sales supervisor, who had taken away certain documents from him and in respect of which he had filed a case against Srivastava, S. N. Mukerjea, General Manager, R. C. Burman, Managing Director and others before the Police Magistrate, Alipore.

facts.text: On August 17, 1959, appellant served notice on complainant to produce specific documents.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1959 the appellant served through companynsel on the companyplainant a numberice to produce in companyrt on August 20, 1959 the following documents Sale Book  Mill Area  for 1958. Collection Register from 2nd January, 1958 upto 15th July, 1958. Challans for the year 1958 as per parcel number etc.

facts.text: Documents listed in notice not produced by complainant.

anchor.surface_text: The documents were number produced. In the cross-examination of some witnesses for the companyplainant a suggestion was made that these documents were withheld because they would have demonstrated that the appellant had deposited the money with the cashier.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate acquitted appellant on March 7, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Presidency Magistrate recorded a judgment of acquittal on March 7, 1960. He was of opinion that the only question was whether the accused had deposited the amount with the cashier of the Company.

facts.text: Magistrate held complainant failed to disprove deposit claim and gave benefit of doubt due to non-production of documents.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the companyplainant had number been able to disprove the claim of the accused  appellant  that he had made the deposit. The learned Magistrate pointed out that some of the documents which the accused  appellant  had asked for were number produced by the companyplainant and the benefit of the doubt ought to go to the accused  appellant .

facts.text: Complainant obtained special leave under s.417(3) CrPC from Calcutta High Court to appeal acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant then obtained special leave under s. 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure from the High Court of Calcutta to appeal against the acquittal.

facts.text: High Court on June 28, 1962 ordered production of specific documents and additional oral evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by S. K. Sen and A. C. Roy JJ. On June 28, 1962, the learned Judges ordered the production of the documents in question Ind the taking of additional oral evidence to prove the documents.

facts.text: High Court set aside acquittal, convicted appellant under s.408 IPC and sentenced as stated on September 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was then heard ind allowed and the acquittal of the appellant was set aside and lie was companyvicted and sentenced as already stated. The High Court held that there was overwhelming evidence to prove the receipt of the three sums by the appellant and that the additional evidence demonstrated clearly that the money received by the appellant was number deposited with the cashier of the Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has filed this appeal by special leave, and it is companytended that the High Court acted beyond the jurisdiction companyferred by s. 428 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in receiving additional evidence which has enabled the prosecution to improve its case.

facts.text: High Court found overwhelming evidence of receipt of sums and non-deposit after additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that there was overwhelming evidence to prove the receipt of the three sums by the appellant and that the additional evidence demonstrated clearly that the money received by the appellant was number deposited with the cashier of the Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court acted within powers under s.428 CrPC in taking additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the High Court acted within the powers companyferred by the Code. The appeal. thus has numbersubstance.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed. No limitation should be placed upon that power unless it be found expressly stated in the Code. But in exercising the power conferred by the Code and before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court should and will always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as  1  the views of the trial Judge as to the credibility of the witnesses  2  the presumption of innocence in favour of the accused, a presumption certainly not weakened by the fact that he has been acquitted at his trial  3  the right of the accused to the benefit of any doubt, and  4  the slowness of an appellate Court in disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a Judge who had the advantage of seeing the witnesses.

concepts.interpretation: High Court has full power to review evidence in acquittal appeal but must consider trial judge's views on credibility, presumption of innocence, benefit of doubt, and reluctance to disturb factual findings

anchor.surface_text: An order for retrial of a criminal case is made in exceptional cases, and not unless the appellate Court is satisfied that the Court trying the proceeding had no jurisdiction to try it or that the trial was vitiated by serious illegalities or irregularities or on account of misconception of the nature of the proceedings and on that account in substance there had been no real trial or that the Prosecutor or an accused was, for reasons over which he had no control, prevented from leading or tendering evidence material to the charge

concepts.interpretation: Retrial ordered only in exceptional cases like lack of jurisdiction, serious irregularities, no real trial, or inability to adduce material evidence

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ode thus gives power to the appellate Court to order one or the other as the circumstances may require leaving a wide discretion to it to deal appropr

arguments.claim: Appellant strongly relies on Abinash Chandra Bose case where High Court set aside acquittal and ordered retrial improperly because prosecution failed to adduce available evidence

anchor.surface_text: The appellant strongly relies upon a decision of this Court reported in Abinash Chandra Bose v. Bimal Krishna Sen and another and the respondents upon Ukha Kolhe v. State of Maharashtra, another case of this Court which is to be found in the same volume at p. 153. Both sides have referred us to many cases decided by the High Courts defining the powers of the appellate Court to take additional evidence.

arguments.claim: No essential difference between taking fresh evidence under s.428 or ordering retrial under s.423; evidence always available, asked at trial but not produced; prosecution should not get second chance

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chakravarti contends that there is noessential difference between the taking of fresh evidence under s. 428 or the ordering of a retrial under s. 423, that this evidence was always available and had, in fact, been asked to be brought in at the trial but was not, and the prosecution should not have another chance whether by way of retrial or additional evidence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: retion was properly exercised. The appellant here had received three sums from the agents and the allegation was that he had misappropriated the amoun

arguments.court_reasoning: Wide discretion under s.428 to take additional evidence if necessary to prevent failure of justice; not limited by retrial conditions; here evidence justified

arguments.claim: Magistrate drew presumption against complainant for failure to produce documents; High Court order deprived appellant of benefit of that presumption

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chakravarti contends that the Magistrate had drawn a presumption against the complainant from the failure of the complainant to produce this evidence and the order of the High Court deprived the appellant of the benefit of the presumption. There is noforce in this argument which may be raised invariably in all cases in which the powers under S. 428 are exercised.

arguments.court_reasoning: No force as argument raisable always; here accused demanded documents, produced after order; interests of justice required it

arguments.claim: Abinash Chandra Bose explained by Ukha Kolhe; latter gives exhaustive circumstances for retrial; outside those, appellate court may order additional evidence if necessary

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad on the other hand explains the Abinash Chandra Boses case with the aid of Ukha Kolhes case and submits that in the latter, this Court gave an exhaustive list of circumstances in which an order for retrial can be made and indicated that in cases falling outside those circumstances, the appellate Court has a discretion to order additional evidence, if considered necessary.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . The power must be exercised sparingly Sup./165--13 and only in suitable cases. Once such action is justified, there is numberrestriction on the kind

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees list not exhaustive but illustrative; wide discretion exists; resemblances between retrial and additional evidence but not to construe one by other

arguments.claim: Code does not differentiate between ambit of appeal from conviction and from acquittal except appeal against conviction as of right

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at once that the Code does not differentiate between the ambit of an. appeal from a conviction and that of an appeal from an order of acquittal except that an appeal against a conviction is as of right and lies to Courts of different jurisdiction depending on the nature of sentence, the kind of trial and the court in which it was held

arguments.claim: Sections 417, 418, 423 give High Court full power to review evidence at large in acquittal appeal, reverse if wrong on evidence, but considering trial judge credibility views, innocence presumption, benefit of doubt, reluctance to disturb facts

anchor.surface_text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be reversed. No limitation should be placed upon that power unless it be found expressly stated in the Code.

arguments.claim: Under s.428, appellate court may take additional evidence if thinks necessary, record reasons; wide discretion dictated by exigency, fair play; necessary because failure of justice without it, sparingly, no prejudice to accused

anchor.surface_text: Section 428 next provides 428. 1 In dealing with any appeal under this Chapter, the Appellate Court, if it thinks additional evidence to be necessary, shall record its reasons, and may either take such evidence itself, or direct it to be taken by a Magistrate, or when the Appellate Court is a High Court, by a Court of Session or a Magistrate.

arguments.claim: High Court properly exercised discretion under s.428 as additional evidence necessary; Magistrate acquitted solely on non-production despite oral evidence of no deposit; fair play required showing documents demanded by accused

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took additional evidence because it was of the opinion that this evidence was necessary. It is manifest that, if the High Court wished to rely on oral evidence, fair play at least demanded that the accused appellant should be given a chance of seeing the documents where the deposit by him would be mentioned, if made.

The learned Magistrate pointed out that some of the documents which the accused appellant had asked for were not produced by the complainant and the benefit of the doubt ought to go to the accused appellant.

holdings.text: The High Court acted within the powers conferred by the Code of Criminal Procedure in receiving additional evidence under s. 428.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the High Court acted within the powers conferred by the Code. The appeal. thus has nosubstance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court recorded reasons, evidence was necessary to prevent failure of justice, documents were those demanded by appellant earlier, fair play required opportunity to rebut oral evidence, discretion properly exercised.

holdings.text: The Code does not differentiate between the ambit of an appeal from a conviction and that of an appeal from an order of acquittal except that an appeal against a conviction is as of right.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at once that the Code does not differentiate between the ambit of an. appeal from a conviction and that of an appeal from an order of acquittal except that an appeal against a conviction is as of right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 418 and 423 provide identical matters appealable and powers in essence the same for both types of appeals.

holdings.text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and to reverse it, subject to considering trial judge's credibility views, presumption of innocence, benefit of doubt, and reluctance to disturb facts.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded, and to reach the conclusion that upon that evidence the order of acquittal should be re- versed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Sheo Swarup principles accepted by Supreme Court; no limitations unless expressly stated in Code.

holdings.text: Additional evidence must be necessary not because it would be impossible to pronounce judgment but because there would be failure of justice without it; power exercised sparingly, without prejudice to accused.

anchor.surface_text: additional evidence must be necessary not because it would be impossible to pronounce judgment but because there would be failure of justice without it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide discretion under s.428 dictated by exigency, fair play; not controlled to specific circumstances; analogy to retrial but not construed thereby.

holdings.text: The limits of the appellate Court's jurisdiction in ordering additional evidence under s.428 were not exceeded by the High Court in this case.

anchor.surface_text: It only remains to determine the limits if any of the jurisdiction and power of the appellate Court here the High Court in ordering additional evidence and whether the limits so determined were exceeded by the High Court in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence always available but demanded by accused; Magistrate acquitted solely on non-production despite oral evidence of no deposit; fair play and justice required production; no second chance to prosecution unfairly.

holdings.text: The conclusion of the High Court on facts is correct once additional evidence rightly received.

anchor.surface_text: This is the only point which was argued and which we need consider, because, if the evidence was rightly received, there is nodoubt that the conclusion of the High Court on fact is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming evidence of receipt; additional evidence clearly showed no deposit.

anchor.surface_text: Sheo Swarup others v. King Emperor 1  in a categoric pronouncement  later accepted by this Court in many cases  that There is numberfoundation for the view apparently supported by the judgments of some Courts in India that the High Court has numberpower or jurisdiction to reverse an order of acquittal on a matter of fact except in cases in which the lower companyrt has obstinately blun

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court in appeal against acquittal has full power to review evidence at large and reverse acquittal, subject to giving proper weight to trial judge's views on credibility, presumption of innocence, benefit of doubt, and slowness to disturb findings based on seeing witnesses
precedents.cited_holding: There is numberfoundation for the view apparently supported by the judgments of some Courts in India that the High Court has numberpower or jurisdiction to reverse an order of acquittal on a matter of fact except in cases in which the lower companyrt has obstinately blundered or has through incompetence, stupidity or perversity reached such distorted companyclusions as to produce a positive miscarriage of justice... Sections 417, 418 and 423 of the Code give to the High Court full power to review at large the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as having no substance; High Court judgment upheld confirming conviction and sentence under s. 408 IPC

Argument a6 that the Code does not differentiate ambit of conviction and acquittal appeals (except as of right) supports holding h3 of full review power in acquittal appeals.
Argument a6 on non-differentiation of appeal ambits addresses issue i5 regarding High Court power to review evidence in acquittal appeals under Sections 417, 418, 423.
Argument a8 on s.428 allowing additional evidence for necessity, reasons, exigency, fair play, and failure of justice supports holding h5 that limits were not exceeded.
